Charles R. Our expresse pleasure is, that this our declaration be published in all churches and chappels within the kingdome of England and dominion of Wales, by the parsons, vicars or curates of the same. Printed by His Majesties command at Oxford.

notesStmt.note: The negotiations mentioned are the King's message of Aug. 25 (quoted in full on A2v-A3r), the Parliament's answer of Aug. 27 (quoted), the King's second message of about Sept. 3 (quoted), the second answer of Sept. 5 (quoted), the third message of Sept. 11 (quoted), and the third reply of about Sept. 16 (quoted).--Cf. Madan 1045.
Imperfect: title page cut at foot, with partial loss of imprint.
Reproductions of the originals in the Huntington Library and Art Gallery (reel 1057) and the Harvard University Library (reel 2205).

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: HIS MAIESTIES Declaration To all His Loving SVBIECTS, Vpon occa≈øion of His late Me≈ø≈øages to both Hou≈øes OF PARLIAMENT, And their refu≈øall to Treat with Him for the Peace of the KINGDOME.

OVr expre≈ø≈øe plea≈øure is, That this Our Declaration be publi≈øhed in all Churches and Chappels within the Kingdome of England and Dominion of Wales, by the Par≈øons, Vicars or Curates of the ≈øame.
Printed by His Maje≈øties Command at Oxford.

div.head: His Maje≈øties Declaration to all His Loving Subjects upon occa≈øion of His late Me≈ø≈øages to both Hou≈øes of Parliament, and their refu≈øall to treat with him for the Peace of the KINGDOME.
div.p: IF it had no evidently appeared to all men who h ve carefully examined and con≈øidered our Actions, Me≈ø≈øages, and Declarations, how farie Wee are and have beene from begetting or promoting the pre≈øent di≈øtractions, and that the Armes we have now taken are for the nece≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ ry ≈øafety and defence of our life, being not taken up by Vs ill our Towne and fort of Hull were kept from Vs by force of Armes, our Navie imployed again≈øt Vs to keepe all forraign e ≈øupply of Armes and Mon y, when our own here was ≈øeized and detained from Vs, and an Army rai≈øed in pay, and marching again≈øt Vs, yet the late reception of our Me≈ø≈øage of the Twentie fifth of Augu≈øt ≈øent by per≈øons of Honour and tru≈øt, will ≈øure ≈øatisfie the world, that we have omitted nothing on Our part that a Gracious and Chri≈øtian Prince could or can doe to prevent the effu≈øion of Chri≈øtian bloud, but that the Malignant party, which have with great ≈øubtilty and in lu≈øtry begot this misunder≈øtanding between Vs and our good Subjects, re≈øolve to ≈øatisfie and ≈øecure their malice and Ambition with the ruine of the kingdome, and in the bloud of Vs, and all Our good Subjects.

When they had forced Vs, after the neglect of our Me≈ø≈øage from Beverly, by rai≈øing a great Army and incen≈øing our Subjects again≈øt Vs, to erect our Royall Standard, that our Subjects might be informed of our danger, and repaire to our Succour, though we had no great rea≈øon to believe any Me≈ø≈øage of ours would receive a very good entertainement, if tho≈øe men might prevaile, who had brought all the≈øe mi≈øeries upon the Kingdome to ≈øatisfie their owne private end: yet ob≈øerving the mi≈øerable Accidents which already befell our good Subjects by the Souldiers under their command, and well
knowing that greater would en≈øue, if timely prevention were not applyed; and finding that the malice and cunning of the≈øe men had infu≈øed into our People a Rumour, that We had rejected all propo≈øitions and offers of Treaty, and de≈øired to engage Our Subjects in a Civill War, which our ≈øoule abhorres, we prevailed with Our≈øelfe (for a full expre≈ø≈øion of Our de≈øire to prevent the effu≈øion of blou ‚Ä¢ ) to ≈øend a gra ‚Ä¢ cous Me≈ø≈øage to both Our Hou≈øes of Parliament on the 25. of Augu≈øt. In the≈øe words,

WE have with un≈øpeakeable griefe of heart long beheld the di≈øtractions of this Our Kingdome,
„Äà‚óä„Äâ Maje
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ s Gra
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ as Me≈ø
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ th hou
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of ‚Ä¢ ar ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ment, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ it from ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ otting
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . Aug. „Äà‚óä„Äâ 42. „Äà‚óä„Äâ the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ cles of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ uthamp „Äà‚óä„Äâ and ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r≈øet, „Äà‚óä„Äâ Iohn ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ alpeper ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ hancel
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r of the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ chequer ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d Sir William ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ dall. Our very ≈øoule is full of angui≈øh untill Wee may find ‚Ä¢ ≈øome remedy to prevent the Mi≈øeries which are ready to overwhelme this whole Nation by a Civill Warre: And though all our endeavours tending to the compo≈øing of tho≈øe unhappy differences betwixt Vs and our two Hou≈øes of Parliament (though pur≈øued by Vs with all Zeale and Syncerity) have beene hitherto without that ≈øucce≈ø≈øe We hoped for; yet ≈øuch is our con≈øtant and earne≈øt care to pre≈øerve the publike Peace, that Wee ≈øhall not bee di≈øcouraged from u≈øing any expedient, which by the ble≈ø≈øing of the God of Mercy may lay a firme foundation of Peace and happine≈ø≈øe to all our good Subjects: To this end ob≈øerving that many mi≈øtakes have ari≈øe ‚Ä¢ by the Me≈ø≈øages, Petitions and An≈øwers betwixt Vs and Our two Hou≈øes of Parliament, which happily may bee prevented by ≈øome other way of Treaty, wherein the Matters in difference may be more cleerely under≈øtood, and more freely tran≈øacted; We have thought fit to propound to you, That ≈øome fit per≈øons may bee by you inable I to Treate with the like number to bee authorized by Vs, in ≈øuch manner, and with ≈øuch freedome of debate, as may be≈øt tend to that happy Conclu≈øion which all good men de≈øire, The peace of the Kingdome: Wherein as We promi≈øe in the word of a King, all ≈øafety and encouragement to ≈øuch as ≈øhall be ≈øent to Vs, if you ≈øhall choo≈øe the place where We are for the Treaty, which We wholy leave to you, pre≈øuming of your like care of the ≈øafety of th ≈øe Wee ≈øhall imploy if you ≈øhall name another place; So We a≈øsure you and all our good Subjects, that (to the be≈øt of our under≈øtanding) ‚Ä¢ othing ≈øhall bee therein wanting on our parts, which may advance the true Prote≈øtant Religion, oppo≈øe Popery and Super≈øtition, ≈ø ‚Ä¢ cure the Law of the Land (upon which is built as well our ju≈øt Prerogative, as the Propriety and Liberty of the Subject) Confirme all ju≈øt Power and Priviledges of Parliament, and render Vs and our people tru ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ y happie by a good nder≈øtanding betwixt Vs and our two Hou≈øes of Parliament. B ‚Ä¢ ing with you as firme Re≈øolutions to doe your duty, and let all our good people j ‚Ä¢ yne with Vs in our prayers to Almighty God for his ble≈ø≈øing upon this worke.

If this propo≈øit on ≈øhall be rejected by you, we have done our duty ≈øo amply, that God will ab≈øolve Vs from the guilt of any of that bloud which mu≈øt be ≈øpilt, and what opinion ≈øoever other men may have of our power, wee a≈ø≈øure
you nothing but our Chri≈øtian and pious care to prevent the Eff ‚Ä¢ ≈øion of bloud hath beg t this Motion, our provi≈øion of Men, Armes and Money being ≈øuch as may ≈øecure Vs from farther violence, till it ≈øhall plea≈øe God to open the eyes of our People.

Our Me≈ø≈øengers were not ≈øuffered to ≈øit in the Hou≈øes, and one of them, the Earle of Southampton (again≈øt whom there was not the lea≈øt colour of exception or ≈øo much as a Vot.) not ≈øuffered to deliver our Me≈ø≈øage, but compelled to ≈øend it by the Gentleman V ‚Ä¢ ber, and then commanded to depart the Town, before they would prepare any An≈øwer which they ≈øhortly ≈øent Vs in the≈øe words.

body.p: THe Lords and Commons in Parliament a≈ø≈øembled, having received your Maje≈øties Me≈ø≈øage of the 25. of Augu≈øt, The An≈øwer of the Lords and Commons to His Maje≈øti s Me≈ø≈øage the 25. of Augu≈øt. 1642. doe with much griefe re≈øent the dangerous and di≈øtracted ≈øtate of this Kingdome, which we have by all mean s endeavoured to prevent, both by our ≈øeverall advices and Petitions to your Maje≈øtie, which have beene not onely without ≈øucce≈ø≈øe, but there hath followed that, which no ill coun≈øell in former times hath produced, or any age hath ≈øeene, namly, tho≈øe ≈øeverall Proclamations and Declarations again≈øt both the Hou≈øes of Parliament, whereby their Actions are declared Trea≈øonable, and their per≈øons traitors; And thereupon your Maje≈øty hath ≈øet up your Standard again≈øt them, whereby you have put the two Hou≈øes of Parliament, an lin them thu whole kingdome out of your Protection; ≈øo that untill your Maie≈øty ≈øhall recall tho≈øe Proclamations and Declarations; whereby the Earle of E≈øt ‚Ä¢ x and both Hou≈øes of Parliament, and their adherents and a≈ø≈øi≈øtants, and ≈øuch as have obeyed and executed their commands and directions, according to their duties, are declared traitors, or otherwi≈øe delinquents; And untill the Standard ≈øet up in pur≈øuance of the ≈øaid Proclamations bee taken downe, your Maie≈øty hath put us into ≈øuch a condition, that while≈øt we ≈øo remaine, we cannot by the ≈øundamentall priviledges of Parliament; the publicke tru≈øt repo≈øed in us; or with the generall good and ≈øafety of this kingdome give your Maie≈øty any other an≈øwer to this Me≈ø≈øage.

closer.signed: Ioh. Browne Cler. Parl. H. El≈øinge Cler. Parl. D. Com.

div.p:
THis ≈øtrange An≈øwer might well have di≈øcouraged Vs from any thought of proceeding further this way, and informed Vs ≈øufficiently what ≈øpirit ≈øtill governed among≈øt tho≈øe few, who continued ≈øtill in both Hou≈øes, therwi≈øe after ≈øo many bitter and invective Me≈øsages and Declarations ≈øent to Vs, and publi≈øhed again≈øt Vs, we ≈øhould not have beene reproached with our Proclamations and Declarations ≈ø ‚Ä¢ t for ‚Ä¢ h by Vs, as the effect of ≈øuch ‚Ä¢ v l ‚Ä¢ Coun≈øell, as was unparalle'd by any former examples. VVe beleeve indeed ≈øuch Proclamations and Declarations have never been before ≈øet forth; but were former times ever acquainted with ≈øuch intolerable provocations? were there ever, before the≈øe Twelve Months, Declarations publi≈øhed in the name of either or both Hou≈øes of Parliament to make their King odious to the people?
Have either or both Hou≈øes ever before a≈øsumed or pretended to a power to rai≈øe Armes or leavie Warre in an cau≈øe, or can both Hou≈øes together exerci≈øe ≈øuch a Power? Are tho≈øe Actions which the Law hath defined literally and expre≈øly to be trea≈øonable, or ≈øuch Per≈øons to be Traitours, not ≈øo becau≈øe they are done by Members of either Hou≈øe, or their appointment? And mu≈øt not We declare ≈øuch who March with Armes and Force to de≈øtroy Vs, to be Traitours, becau≈øe the Earle of E≈ø≈øex is their Generall? Tho≈øe whom Wee have or doe accu≈øe, We have named together with their Crimes, notorious by the knowne Law of the Land, (a favour not granted to our Evill Coun≈øellors) and appeale to that knowne Law to judge betweene Vs: And now that by this we ≈øhould have put the whole Kingdome out of our Protection (in who≈øe behalfe we do all that we have done) is a corrupt Glo≈øse upon ≈øuch a Text, as cannot bee perverted but by the cunning practices of ≈øuch who wi≈øh not well to King or People, yet that no weake Per≈øons might bee mi≈øled by that imputation upon Vs, we ≈øent a Reply to that An≈øwer in the≈øe words.

WEE will not repeate what meanes We have u≈øed to prevent the dangerous and di≈øtracted e≈øtate of the Kingdome,
‚Ä¢ is Maje
‚Ä¢ ies Reply „Äà‚óä„Äâ an An
‚Ä¢ wer ≈øent ‚Ä¢ y the two ‚Ä¢ ou≈øes of ‚Ä¢ arlia
‚Ä¢ ent to ‚Ä¢ is Maje
‚Ä¢ ies Me≈ø
‚Ä¢ age of the ‚Ä¢ 5. of Aug Concerning a trea
‚Ä¢ e of accoÃÑ
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ odation. nor how tho≈øe meanes have beene interpreted, becau≈øe being de≈øirous ‚Ä¢ o avoyd effu≈øion of bloud, We are willing to decline all memory of former bitterne≈ø≈øe that might make Our offer of a Treaty le≈ø≈øe readily accepted.

We never did Declare, nor ever intended to Declare both Our Hou≈øes of Parliament Traitours, or ≈øet up Our Standard again≈øt them, and much le≈ø≈øe to put them and this Kingdome out of Our Protection: Wee utterly profe≈ø≈øe again≈øt it before God and the World. And further to remove all po≈ø≈øible Scruples which may hinder the Treaty ≈øo much de≈øired by Vs; We hereby promi≈øe, ≈øo that a day be appointed by you for the revoking of your declarations, again≈øt all Per≈øons as Traitours or other wayes, for a≈ø≈øi≈øting of Vs, wee ≈øhall with all cheerefulne≈øse upon the ≈øame day recall our Proclamations & Declarations and take downe Our Standard: In which Treaty We ≈øhall be ready to grant any thing that ≈øhall bee really for the good of Our Subjects; Conjuring you to con≈øider the bleeding condition of Jreland, and the dangerous condition of England, in as high a degree as by the≈øe Our offers We have declared Our ≈øelfe to do: And a≈ø≈øuring you that Our chiefe de≈øire in this world is to beg ‚Ä¢ t a good under≈øtanding and mutuall confidence betwixt Vs and Our two Hou≈øes of Parliament.

THis Me≈ø≈øage produced an An≈øwer little differing from the former, like men who had no other mea≈øure of the Ju≈øtice of their cau≈øe, then their power to oppre≈ø≈øe Vs, forgetting their owne duties, they ≈øharply informe Vs of Ours in the≈øe words,

body.p:
If We the Lords and Commons in Parliament A≈ø≈øembled,The hu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ble an≈øwer and Pet ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ on of th ‚Ä¢ Lords a ‚Ä¢ Commo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ A≈ø≈øemb ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ in Parl ‚Ä¢
ment, u ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the King ‚Ä¢ la≈øt Me≈ø ‚Ä¢
age. ≈øhould Repeal all the wayes wee have taken, the endeavours we have u≈øed, and the expre≈ø≈øions wee have made unto Your Maje≈øtic to prevent thefe di≈øtractions, and dangers Your Maje≈øty ≈øpeakes of, likely to fall upon this Kingdome, we ≈øhould too much inlarge this reply, Therefore as wee humbly, ≈øo ≈øhall we onely let Your Maje≈øty know, that we cannot Recede from our former An≈øwer for the rea≈øons therein expre≈ø≈øed. For that Your Maje≈øty hath not taken down ‚Ä¢ your Standard, rec ‚Ä¢ l led Your Proclamations and Declarations, whereby You have declared the Actions of both Hou≈øes of Parliament to bee Trea≈øenable and their per≈øons Traytors. And you have publi≈øhed the ≈øame ≈øince Your Me≈ø≈øage of the twentie fifth of Augu≈øt by your late in≈øtructions ≈øent to your Commi≈ø≈øioners of Aray, which Standard bring taken downe, and the Declarations, Proclamations and in≈øtructions recalled, If your Maje≈øtic ≈øhall then upon this our humble perition, leaving Your Forces, returne unto your Parliament, and receive their faithfull advice, Your Maiesty will finde ≈øuch expre≈ø≈øions of our fidelities and duties, as ≈øhall a≈ø≈øure You that Your ≈øafety, Honour and greatne≈ø≈øe can only be found in the affections of Your people, and the ≈øincere Coun≈øells of Your Parliament, who≈øe con≈øtant, and undi≈øcouraged endeavours, and con≈øultations have pa≈ø≈øed through difficulties unheard of, onely to ≈øecure Your Kingdomes from the violent Mi≈øchiefes and dangers now ready to fall upon them, and every part of them, who de≈øerve better of Your Maje≈øty, and can never allow them≈øelves (repre≈øenting likewi≈øe your whole Kingdome) to be ballanced with tho≈øe per≈øons who≈øe de≈øperate di≈øpo≈øitions and coun≈øells prevaile, ≈øtill ≈øo to interrupt all our endeavours for the relieving of bleeding Ireland, as we may feare our labours, and va≈øt expences will be fruitle≈ø≈øe to that di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Kingdome. As your pre≈øence is thus humbly de≈øired by us; So is it in our hopes your Maje≈øty will in your rea≈øon believe, there is no other way then this, to make your ≈øelfe happie, and your Kingdome ≈øafe.

div.p: WIthout any bitterne≈ø≈øe or reprehen≈øion of their neglect of Vs, and the publike Peace, to expre≈ø≈øe Our deepe ≈øen≈øe of the Calemities at hand, We yet once more (hoping to awake them to a Chri≈øtian tenderne≈ø≈øe towards the whole Kingdome) ≈øent to them in the≈øe words.

WHo have taken mo≈øt wayes, u≈øed mo≈øt endeavours, and made mo≈øt reall expre≈ø≈øions to prevent the pre≈øent di≈øtractions and dangers, let all the world judge, as well by former Pa≈ø≈øages as by our two la≈øt Me≈ø≈øages, which have beene ≈øo fruitle≈ø≈øe, that (though wee have de≈øcended to de≈øire and pre≈ø≈øe it) not ≈øo much as a Treaty can be obtained, unle≈ø≈øe we would denude our ≈øelfe of all force to defend Vs from a vi≈øible ≈øtrength marching again≈øt Vs, and admit tho≈øe Per≈øons as Traitors to Vs, who according to their duty, their Oaths of Allegiance, and the Law, have appeared in defence of Vs their King and Liege Lord (whom we are bound in Con≈øcience and Honour to pre≈øerve) though we di≈øclaimed all our Proclamations and Declarations, and the erecting of our Standard as again≈øt our Parliament. All we have now left in our Power is to expre≈ø≈øe the deepe ≈øen≈øe wee have of the publike mi≈øery of this Kingdome, in which is involved that of Our di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Prote≈øtants of Ireland, and to apply our ≈øelfe to our nece≈ø≈øary defence, wherein we wholly rely upon the Providence of God, and the ju≈øtice of our Cau≈øe, and the affection of our good People, ≈øo far we are from putting them out of our protection. VVhen you ≈øhall de≈øire a Treaty of Vs, we ≈øhall piou≈øly remember who≈øe blond is to be ≈øpilt in this quarrell, and cheerefully embrace it: And as no other Rea≈øon induced Vs to leave our Citie of London, but that with honour and ≈øafety we could not ≈øtay there, nor rai≈øe any force but for the nece≈ø≈øary defence of our Per≈øon and the Law, again≈øt Leavies in oppo≈øition to both, ≈øo we ≈øhall ≈øuddenly and mo≈øt willingly returne to the one, and disband the other, as ≈øoone as tho≈øe cau≈øes ≈øhall bee removed. The God of Heaven direct you, and in mercy divert tho≈øe judgements which hang over this Nation, and ≈øo deale with Vs and our Po≈øterity as We de≈øire the Pre≈øervation and Advancement of the true Prote≈øtant Religion, the Lawes and the Libertie of the Subiect, the iu≈øt Rights of Parliament, and the Peace of the Kingdome.

BVt as if all the≈øe Gracious Me≈ø≈øages had beene the effects only of our weakne≈ø≈øe, and in≈øtances of Our want of Power to re≈øi≈øt that torment, they deale at la≈øt more plainly with Vs, and after many ≈øharpe, cau≈øele≈ø≈øe, and unju≈øt reproaches, they tell Vs in plaine Engli≈øh, that without putting our Selfe ab≈øolutly into their hands, and de≈øerting all our owne Force, and the protection of all tho≈øe who have faithfully appeared for Vs according to their duty, there would be no meanes of a Treaty, although our extraordinary de≈øire of Peace had prevailed with Vs, to offer to recall our mo≈øt ju≈øt Declarations, and to take downe our Standard, ≈øet up for our nece≈ø≈øary defence, ≈øo their unju≈øtifiable Declarations might bee likewi≈øe recalled, their An≈øwer followes in the≈øe words,

body.p:
WEE the Lords and Commons in Parliament A≈ø≈øembled, do pre≈øent this our humble An≈øwer to Your Maje≈øties Me≈ø≈øage of the eleventh of this in≈øtant Month of Septem. when wee con≈øider the oppre≈ø≈øions, Rapines, Firing of Hou≈øes,The hu ‚Ä¢
ble An≈øwer of the Lord and Commons A ‚Ä¢
≈øemble d ‚Ä¢ in Parliament un ‚Ä¢ His Maj ‚Ä¢
≈øties la≈øt Me≈ø≈øage. Murthers, (even at this time, whilest Your Majesty propounds a Treaty) committed upon Your good Subjects by Your Souldiers, in the pre≈øence, and by the Authority of their Commanders, being of the number of tho≈øe whom Your Maje≈øty holds Your ≈øelfe bound in Honour and Con≈øcience to protect as per ons doing their duties. We cannot thinke Your Maje≈øty hath don ‚Ä¢ all that in You lies to prevent, or remove the pre≈øent distractions; nor ≈øo long as Your Majesty will admit no peace without ≈øecuring the Authors and Instruments of the≈øe mi≈øchi ‚Ä¢ fes from the Iu≈øtice of the Parliament, which yet ≈øhall bee ever di≈øpenced with all requi≈øite moderation and di≈øtinction of offences, Although ≈øome of tho≈øe per≈øons be ≈øuch in who≈øe pre≈øervation Your Kingdome cannot be ≈øafe, nor the unque≈øtionable rights and Priviledges of Parliament be maintained, without which the power and dignity thereof will fall into contempt. We be≈øeech Your Maje≈øty therefore to con≈øider Your expre≈ø≈øions, That God ≈øhould deale with You and Your po≈øterity, as Your Maje≈øty de≈øir ‚Ä¢ s the pre≈øervation of the Ju≈øt Rights of Parliament, which being undeniable in the trying of ≈øuch as We have declared to bee Delinquents, We ≈øhall believe Your Majesty both towards Your ≈øelfe and Parliament will not in this priviledge, We are mo≈øt ≈øen≈øible of, deny us that which belongs unto the meane≈øt Court of Iu≈øtice in this Kingdome. Neither hath Your Maje≈øty cau≈øe to complain that You are denied a Treaty, when We offer all that a Treaty can produce, or Your Majesty expect, Security, Honour, Service, Obedience, Support, and all other effects of an Humble, Loyall, and faithfull ≈øubjection, and ≈øeeke nothing but that our Religion, Liberty, peace of the Kingdome, ≈øafety of the Parliament may be ≈øecured from the open violence, and cunning practices of a wicked party, who have long plotted our ruine and de≈øtruction; And if there were any cau≈øe of Treaty, we know no competent Per≈øons to Treat betwixt the King and Parliament, And if both cau≈øe and per≈øons were ≈øuch as to invite Treaty, the ≈øea≈øon is altogether unfit, while≈øt Your Maje≈øties Standard is up, and Your Preclamations and Declarations unrecalled, whereby Your Parliament is charged with Trea≈øon.

If Your Maje≈øty ≈øhall per≈øi≈øt to make Your ≈øelfe a ≈øhield and defence to tho≈øe In≈øtruments, and ≈øhall continue to reject our faithfull and nece≈ø≈øary advice for ≈øecuring and main ‚Ä¢ aing Religion and Liberty, with the Peace of the Kingdome and ≈øafety of the Parliament, Wee doubt not but to indifferent judgements it will ea≈øily appeare who is mo≈øt tender of that innocent Bloud which is like to be ≈øpilt in this cau≈øe, Your Maje≈øty, who by ≈øuch per≈øisting, doth endanger Your ≈øelfe and Your Kingdomes, or We, who are willing to hazard our ≈øelves, to pre≈øerve both. Wee humbly be≈øeech Your Majesty to con≈øider how impo≈ø≈øible it is, that any Prote≈øtation, though publi≈øhed in Your Maje≈øties name, of the tenderne≈ø≈øe of the mi≈øeries of Your Prote≈øtant Subjects in Jreland, of Your Re≈øolution to maintaine the Prote≈øtant Religion, and Lawes of this Kingdome, can give ≈øatisfaction to rea≈øonable and indifferent Men, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ
of them, and agents for them, are admitted to Your Maje≈øties pre≈øence with Grace and Favour, and ≈øome of them imployed in Your ≈øervice; when the Cloaths, Munition, Hor≈øes, and other Nece≈ø≈øaries bought by Your Parliament and ≈øent for the ≈øupply of the Army against the Rebells there, are violently taken away, ≈øome by Your Maje≈øties command, others by Your Mini≈øters, and applyed to the maintenance of an unnaturall War against your people here.

All this notwithstanding as we never gave Your Maje≈øty any ju≈øt cau≈øe of withdrawing Your ≈øelfe from Your great Councell, ≈øo it hath ever been, and ≈øhall ever be farre from us to give any impediment to your returne, or to neglect any proper means of curing the di≈øtempers of the Kingdom, and clo≈øing the dangerous Breaches betwixt Your Majesty and Your Parliament, according to the great trust which lies upon us, and if Your Majesty ≈øhall now be plea≈øed to come back to Your Parliament, without Your Forces, we ≈øhall be ready to ≈øecure Your Royall Per≈øon, Your Crowne, and Dignity, with our Lives and Fortunes, Your pro≈øence in this Your great Councell, being the only means of any Treaty betwixt Your Majesty and them with hope of Succe≈ø≈øe.

And in none of our de≈øires to Your Maje≈øty ≈øhall we be ≈øwayed by any particular mans advantage, but ≈øhall give a clear Te≈øtimony to Your Maje≈øty, and the whole World, that in all things done by us, we faithfully intend the good of your Maje≈øty, and of Your Kingdoms, and that we will not be diverted from this end by any private, or ≈øelfe re≈øpects what≈øoever.

div.p:
THey will not beleeve we have done all that in us lyes to prevent and remove the pre≈øent Di≈øtractions, becau≈øe of the oppre≈ø≈øions, rapines, and the like committed upon our good Subjects by our ≈øouldiers. Let them remember who have compelled us, and again≈øt our ≈øoules de≈øire, forced us to rai≈øe tho≈øe ≈øouldiers, and then if the oppre≈ø≈øions and rapines were indeed ≈øuch as are fal≈øely pretended, our poore Subjects who ≈øuffer under them, will looke on them, and only on them, as the Authors of all the mi≈øeries they do or can undergo, we confe≈ø≈øe with grief of heart ≈øome di≈øorders have, and many more may befall our good people by our ≈øouldiers, but we appeal to all tho≈øe Counties through which we have pa≈ø≈øed, what care we have taken to prevent, and what Iu≈øtice we dayly inflict upon ≈øuch offendours: neither hath the lea≈øt complaint been ever made to us of violences and outrages, which we have not to our utmo≈øt power repayred or puni≈øhed; how ever tho≈øe fal≈øe & trea≈øonable PaÃÑ phlets are ≈øuffered which accu≈øe us of giving warrant for plandring of hou≈øes. Our Mercy and Lenity is ≈øo well knowne to the contrary, that it is u≈øually made an excu≈øe by tho≈øe who again≈øt their con≈øciences a≈ø≈øi≈øt this rebellion again≈øt us,
that they cau≈øe rather to offend us upon the confidence of pardon, then provoke tho≈øe Malignant per≈øons who without charity or companion de≈øtroy all who concurr not with them in faction and opinion. How farr we are from rapine and oppre≈ø≈øion may appear by our Lenity to the per≈øons and E≈øtates of tho≈øe who have not only exerci≈øed the Militia (the ≈øeed from whence this rebellion again≈øt us hath growne) but contributed money and plate to the maintenance of that Army which now endeavours to de≈øtroy us, as of Nottingham, Leice≈øter, and many other places through which we have pa≈ø≈øed many of whom then were and now are in that Army: to let pa≈ø≈øe our pa≈ø≈øing by Chartly (the hou≈øe of the Earle of E≈ø≈øex) without other pre≈ø≈øures then as if he were the Generall of our owne Army, and our expre≈ø≈øe orders to re≈øtraine the Liberty, our ≈øouldiers would otherwi≈øe have u≈øed upon that place, and his E≈øtate about it. How contrary the proceedings are of the≈øe great A≈ø≈øertors of the publique Liberties, appears fully by the ≈øaid in≈øtances they every ‚Ä¢ ay give in the plundring by publick warrant, the hou≈øes of all ≈øuch who≈øe duty, con≈øcience, and loyalty hath engaged them in our Quarrell, which every good man ought to make his owne. By their declaring all per≈øons to be out of the protection of Parliament (and ≈øo expo≈øing them to the fury of their ≈øouldiers) who will not a≈ø≈øi≈øt this rebellion again≈øt us, their anointed King, by the dayly outrages committed in York≈øhire, when contrary to the de≈øire and agreement of that County (≈øigned under the hands of both partyes) they will not ≈øuffer the peace to be kept, but that the di≈øtractions and confu≈øion may be univer≈øall over the whole Kingdome, direct their Governour of Hull to make Warr upon our good Subjects in that County, and ≈øo continue the robbing and plundring the hou≈øes of all ≈øuch who concurr not with them in this rebellion. La≈øtly, by the barbarous, ≈øacrilegious inhumanity exerci≈øed by their ≈øouldiers in Churches, as in Canterbury, Worce≈øter, Oxford, and other places, where they committed ≈øuch unheard of outrages, as I ‚Ä¢ wes, and Athei≈øts, never practi≈øed before. God in his good time will make them examples of his vengeance.

VVe never did, nor ever ≈øhall de≈øire to ≈øecure the Authors and in≈øtruments of any mi≈øchiefs to the Kingdome from the Iu≈øtice of Parliament, we de≈øire all ≈øuch per≈øons may be ≈øpeedily brought to condigne puni≈øhment by that rule which is, or ought to be, the rule of all puni≈øhment, the knowne Law of the Land, if there have ≈øeemed to be any interruption in proceedings of this nature, it mu≈øt be remembred, how long per≈øons have been kept under generall accu≈øations, without tryall, though earne≈øtly de≈øired, that the Members who were properly to judge ≈øuch accu≈øations have by violence been driven thence, or could not with honour and ≈øafety be pre≈øent at ≈øuch debates, that notorious Delinquents by the knowne Lawes were protected again≈øt us from the Iu≈øtice of the Kingdome, and ≈øuch called Delinquents, who committing no offence again≈øt any knowne Law were ≈øo voted only for doing their duties to us, and then there will be no cau≈øe of complaint found again≈øt us.

And for the priviledges of Parliament We have ≈øaid ≈øo much and upon ≈øuch rea≈øons, (which have never beene an≈øwered but by bare po≈øitive A≈ø≈øertions) in our ≈øeverall Declarations, that wee may well, and doe ≈øtill u≈øe the ≈øame expre≈ø≈øion, That we de≈øire God may ≈øo deale with Vs and our po≈øterity, as we de≈øire the pre≈øervation of the ju≈øt Rights of Parliament.

The violation whereof in truth by the≈øe de≈øperate Per≈øons is ≈øo cleerely known to all men who under≈øtand the priviledges of Parliament, that their rage and malice hath not beene greater to Our Per≈øon and Government then to the Liberty, priviledge, and very being of Parliaments, witne≈ø≈øe their putting imputting out, & ≈øu≈øpending what per≈øons they plea≈øe, as they dislike their opinions, their bringing cowne the Tumults to a≈ø≈øault the Members, and awe the Parliament, their po≈øting and pro≈øecuting ≈øuch Members of either Hou≈øe as concurred not with them in their De≈øignes, and ≈øo driving them from thence for the ≈øafety of their lives, their denying Vs, again≈øt the knowne, e≈øtabli≈øhed Law, and the Con≈øtitution of the kingdome, to have a negative voyce, without which no Parliament can con≈øi≈øt, their making clo≈øe Committees, from whence the Members of the Hou≈øes are exempted, again≈øt the Liberty of Parliament, and la≈øtly re≈øolving both Hou≈øes into a clo≈øe Committee, of ≈øeventeene per≈øons who undertake and direct all the pre≈øent outrages and the managery of this Rebellion again≈øt Vs, in the ab≈øence of foure parts of five of both Hou≈øes, and without the privity of tho≈øe who ≈øtay there, which is not only contrary but de≈øtructive to Parliaments them≈øelves. By the≈øe gro≈ø≈øe, unheard of Inva≈øions and breaches of the Privledges of Parliament, (and without them they could not have done the other) They made way for their attempts upon the Law of the Land, and the introduction of that unlimited, Arbitrary power which they have ≈øince exerci≈øed to the intolerable da mage and confu≈øion of the whole kingdome, And We a≈ø≈øure Our good Subjects the Vindication of the≈øe ju≈øt Liberties and Priviledges of Parliament, thus violated by the≈øe men, is not le≈ø≈øe the Argument of our pre≈øent quarrell and undertaking, then our owne Honour, Intere≈øt, and ≈øafety, tho≈øe being no way ≈øo ≈øecurely to bee pre≈øerved, as by pre≈øerving Parliaments and their ju≈øt Priviledges. Neither is there any Prote≈øtation to our knowledge publi≈øhed in our name of our tenderne≈ø≈øe of the mi≈øeries of Ireland, and our Re≈øolution to maintaine the Prote≈øtant Religion, and Lawes of this Kingdome, that is not the Prote≈øtation of our Soule, and manife≈øted in all our actions, and Wee hope that fal≈øe Scandall, That diver≈øe of the Iri≈øh Traitours and Rebels, the knowne favourers of them, and Agents for them are admitted to our pre≈øence with favour and imployed in our ≈øervice, will gaine no credit with good men, who remember well the notorious imputation ≈øo confidently and groundle≈øsly heretofore ca≈øt on us by Ma≈øter Pym, of which as there could never be the lea≈øt proofe, ≈øo we could never receive any ≈øatisfaction for that high in jury, which might have beene a warning to them to have publi≈øhed no more ≈øuch untruths, if they had not found that truth and their Ends cannot meet together.

For the Hor≈øes taken for our Service, which were provided for the ≈øervice of
Ireland, It is true, Wee were compelled for the bringing our owne waggons from Chester for the Carriage of our Munition to make u≈øe of them being few in number and of ≈ømall value, after they were certified to bee of no u≈øe for the ≈øervice, for which they were provided. And for the Clothes, upon enquiry We find that ≈øome few were taken by our Souldiers (but without any order from Vs) going to Coventry, and as was probably believed for the reliefe of that place, then in actuall Rebellion again≈øt Vs, but how farre we have bin, and are from diverting any of tho≈øe provi≈øions made for the reliefe of that poore Kingdome (the thought of who≈øe mi≈øerable condition makes our heart bleed) may appeare by our expre≈ø≈øe command given for the ≈øpeedy tran≈øportation of 3000. ≈øuites of Clothes which Wee found provided at Che≈øter, but neglected to bee ≈øent, and which no nece≈ø≈øity of our owne Army here could prevaile with us to ≈øeize. And how bold ≈øoever the reproaches of that kind have ‚Ä¢ in upon Vs, we are confident malice it ≈øelfe cannot lay the lea≈øt probable imputation upon us, for the neglect of our duty towards that Kingdome. What one thing in our power have wee neglected or omitted, which might contribute to the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, or ea≈øe of our poore Prote≈øtant Subjects there? we fir≈øt recommended the ca≈øe of that bu≈øine≈ø≈øe to both our Hou≈øes of Parliament. We con≈øented to all propo≈øitions made on the behalfe offered to rai≈øe 10000. Voluntiers, (which if then accepted had ≈øhortned that worke) offered to venture our owne per≈øon in the ≈øervice, what interpretation that offer of ours found, is knowne to all the world, wee parted with our Intere≈øt in the Land of the Rebels, to encourage ≈øuch who were willing to adventure in that bu≈øine≈ø≈øe, and when Money is rai≈øed by our con≈øent for that ≈øole purpo≈øe, they have at once ≈øeized on a hundred thou≈øand pound particularly appointed by Act of Parliament for the reliefe of Jreland (our Army being ready to peri≈øh for want of it) and imployed it to maintaine this unnaturall civill Warre at home. They have Leavied men and entertained Commanders for that ≈øervice, and t ‚Ä¢ ed compelled them to joyne in this Rebellion, and to march again≈øt us, and though they have complained of our keeping the Liev tenant of Ireland ≈øome weeks with us, (when in truth it was a ≈øea≈øon of extraordinary bu≈øines,) after we had in vaine for many Moneths pre≈ø≈øed his di≈øpatch, yet them≈øelves now detaine him, when his going is ≈øo nece≈ø≈øary for the pre≈øervation of that Kingdome. And no doubt the≈øe men (and the≈øe alone) by begetting this mi≈øerable di≈øtraction of England, are guilty before God and Man of all the in≈øupportable calamities that our Kingdome of Jreland endures. Let all the world judge where the de≈øire of peace is, and upon who≈øe account the bloud and confu≈øion which hath beene ≈øhed and mu≈øt follow, ≈øhall be ca≈øt, And whether the ≈øeverall Proclamations and Declarations publi≈øhed by us, have not beene extorted from us, by ≈øuch unheard of in≈øolencies and injuries, which no former times ever produced, neither can any ≈øober man wonder when Wee are publikely reproached, traduced, and reviled to our people (a practice never knowne till this Parliament) that We endeavour by a true relation and Declaration of our Actions and Intentions, and of their Con≈øpiracies, who have vowed our de≈øtruction,
to informe our good Subjects of the cunning and malice they are to encounter with; and when a Combination is entred into to de≈øtroy Vs, and to alter the Religion and Law of the Kingdome, and to that purpo≈øe an Army rai≈øed and marching again≈øt us, that We proclaime the Generall of that Army and ≈øuch who ≈øhall a≈ø≈øi≈øt him in leavying a warre again≈øt us, to be Traitours and have ≈øet up our Royall Standard, and required all our good Subjects to come to our defence. And yet both in that Proclamation and in all our Declarations we have never accu≈øed our Parliament, but ≈øuch factious, ≈øeditious Members of both Hou≈øes whom we have named, and whom We are ready to prove according to the rules of the knowne Law to be guilty of High Trea≈øon. We well know, and all the Kingdom knowes that of neere 500. Members, which the Hou≈øe of Commons contaynes, there remaines not now there 100. neither hath above ≈øuch a number con≈øented almo≈øt to any thing of which wee have ever complained, the re≈øt have either beene driven away by Tumults and Threats of the Per≈øons whom we have accu≈øed, or out of Con≈øcience withdrawne them≈øelves from their de≈øperate Con≈øultations, and of about 100. Peeres of the Realme, there are not above 15. or 16. who concurre in the≈øe mi≈øerable Re≈øolutions, which di≈øturbe the publike Peace, many of which being of de≈øperate fortunes, have no other ≈øupport, then the commands now given them to make war upon us, and now the≈øe men mu≈øt ≈øit upon the lives and fortunes of all the Nobility, Gentry, and Commons of England, and becau≈øe we will not put our ≈øelfe into the hands, Government, and di≈øpo≈øall of them, all our good Subjects are invited and encouraged to rebell again≈øt us, yet we have beene, and are ≈øtill farre from accu≈øing all that ≈ømall number of both Hou≈øes who are yet left together, we believe many of them are mi≈øled by the cunning and malice, and frighted by the power of tho≈øe men whom we have accu≈øed, again≈øt every one of whom we have evidence of matter of fact, that the knowne Law of the Land determines to be High Trea≈øon.

And now that all Our good Subjects may ≈øee how de≈øirous the≈øe men and their adherents are to prevent the effu≈øion of bloud, and the la≈øting mi≈øeries of a Civill Warre, they will make them≈øelves ≈øo con≈øiderable, that except we will recall our Proclamations and Declarations whereby particular men named for particular Actions (which the Law hath defined to be Trea≈øon) are ≈øo accu≈øed, and others warned from involving them≈øelves in their guilt, and except we will take downe our Standard, that our good Subjects may not repaire to us for our defence, when ≈øo many Armies are rai≈øed again≈øt us in ≈øeverall parts of the kingdome, and ready to de≈øtroy us, and ≈øuch of our good Subjects, who dare continue loyall to us, and except we will returne to London, from whence with violence we have beene driven, we mu≈øt not be treated with, or receive any An≈øwer to ≈øo gratious a Me≈ø≈øage.

It can no longer be doubted by any man, who hath not wilfully for≈øaken his under≈øtanding, that it is no more a quarrell undertaken by the Parliament, but contrived and fomented by the per≈øons we have named, and now continued ≈øolely in their defence, to who≈øe Ambition, Faction, and Malice, the true reformed
prote≈øtant Religion, the ju≈øt Right, Honour, Safety, and life of us and our po≈øterity the Law of the Land, which hath ≈øo long pre≈øerved this Nation happy, the liberty of the Subject e≈øtabli≈øhed by that Law, and the glorious frame and con≈øtitution of this kingdome mu≈øt be ≈øacrificed. But as we have hitherto left no Action unperformed, which in honour, ju≈øtice and Con≈øcience we were obliged to doe, or in Chri≈øtian policy and prudence wee could conceave might probably prevent the≈øe Calamities, ≈øo we thanke God he hath given us a full courage and re≈øolution to run the utmo≈øt hazard of our life for the ≈øuppre≈ø≈øion of this horrible Rebellion, in the which no di≈øproportion of power, Armes, or money ≈øhall di≈øcourage us; And we hope that all our good Subjects be≈øides, by the common duty of Allegiance, will bee ≈øtirred up for their owne ≈øakes, for the pre≈øervation of the ble≈ø≈øed Prote≈øtant Religion, and for the upholding this whole admirable frame of Government which being di≈ø≈øolved, all their private and particular rights and Intere≈øt mu≈øt bee immediately confounded, to bring in their utmo≈øt power and a≈ø≈øi≈øtance unto us in this de≈øperate exigent. And We doe declare that who≈øoever ≈øhall lo≈øe his life in this Service for our defence, the Ward≈øhip of his Heyre ≈øhall be granted by us without rent or Fyne to his owne u≈øe, and we ≈øhall hold our ≈øelfe obliged to take all po≈ø≈øible care for the ≈øupport, reliefe, and protection of all their wives, and Children, who ≈øhall have the hard fortune to dye in this Service.
